statement.tex: %text If $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{1}$, $\ora{b}=\vector{4}{-2}{3}$ and $\ora{c}=\vector{1}{-2}{1}$, find a vector of magnitude $6$ units which is parallel to $2\ora{a}-\ora{b}+3\ora{c}$. %

step.context: %text If $\ora{A}=\vector{1}{-2}{2}$ were to be expressed as $p\hat A$, where $\hat A$ is the unit vector in the direction of $\ora{A}$ and $p$ is a scalar, what would it look like? %
step.reason: \begin{align} \ora{A} &= \vector{1}{-2}{2} \\ \therefore |\ora{A}| &= \sqrt{(1)^2+(-2)^2+(2)^2} \\ &= \sqrt{1+4+4}=3 \end{align} \\ %text $|\ora{A}|=3$, therefore by factoring out $3$ from $\ora{A}$, we can get its unit vector. % \begin{align} \ora{A}&= \vector{1}{-2}{2} \\ &=3\left(\vector{\dfrac{1}{3}}{-\dfrac{2}{3}}{\dfrac{2}{3}}\right) \\ &=3\hat A \end{align} \\ %text Note: $|\hat A|=\sqrt{\dfrac{1}{9}+\dfrac{4}{9}+\dfrac{4}{9}}=1$ %
